intro: Silene secundiflora subsp. secundiflora, commonly known as the red sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its erect, branched stems and clusters of small, pink to red flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are linear and often covered with fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. Silene secundiflora subsp. secundiflora is an important species in its native habitat, contributing to local biodiversity and providing nectar for pollinators.
